37878785.review:
I was playing a lot of action RPG, FPS and arcade games recently and felt like I was a bit tired of it and wanted to try something completely different and new. After a bit of brainstorming, I remembered that I still never tried Paradigm, a highly acclaimed point'n'click adventure.

To be honest, when I first saw it on Steam, I checked screenshots and videos and was a bit confused of what I saw in there - everything was complete weird, creepy and inadequate. So I thought it was going to be another stupid p'n'c with ridiculous puzzles and humour category "B" .
So I passed at that time. Then I saw it has a pretty good score and some of my friends recommended this game, so I bought it on sale. 

So, Paradigm. One of the weirdest shіt I ever played! I was right a bit about its ridiculous puzzles, though you cant complain about such thing in a game like this. On the other hand, every move you make has its own "reasonable" explanation in a further playthrough. But puzzles are not the main thing in this game. The real gem here is its characters and its deep stupid and,at the same time, clever humour, with a bunch of different refferences. Another thing to mention, is, of course, highly artistic style-unique illustrations in game and attention to the details, which make this game so adorable and amazing at the same time.     

You are playing as a...whatever it is. I mean, I don't wanna spoil it for you, you should see it and experience it for yourself. That's the whole point of the game - it has a lot of hidden messages and deep meaning, which everyone should discover and find answers for yourself. The whole atmosphere is so charming and disturbing at the same time, that you eager to stay in that universe as long as possible to solve all these puzzles, to click every item, to listen to all these ridiculous and funny dialogues with a bunch of sarcastic answers and funny responses, which can easily become a golden quotes, somewhere in the future. I really don't want to spoil it for you, it's just mesmerizing and you should experience everything by yourself without any knowledge of what you are going to face further. It's an unique product which you can enjoy only once in a few years, so do your best to enjoy it as much as possible!

This is a perfect example of what a masterpiece p'n'c game should look like, how the money gathered from the backers should be spent, how your work should be done with all passion and respect to yourself and your customers.       

So, to sum everything up!
You should grab this game if you:

+ Love classic point and click games
+ Love to enjoy artistic detailed well drawn illustrations
+ Missed that type of games, full of unique funny characters, bunch of smart dark humor and cool references to other games, movies, TV shows, etc.
+ Wanna spend a really fun evening or two playing an amazing game

Recommend to avoid if you:

- Expect a really long game. Game can be beated in 3 hours easily, or even less, if you are smart enough :)
- Love difficult brainstorming puzzles. Puzzles are pretty much easy in here, I was literally stucked only for a 2 times and when I came to the conclusion, it looked pretty much obvious to me and I felt dumb.
- Don't like weird unusual unexplainable surrealistic stuff, this game is all about that,

Enjoy!

Honestly, I just love absolutely everything about this game. Worth buying, worth clicking that damn button so many times my hand started hurting. 

It's one of those games that's really hard to explain to someone, you just have to experience it yourself.

37089283.review:
[h1] Hello, can you beatbox? [/h1]

[b]Paradigm[/b] - это одна из лучших оригинальных адвенчур старой школы, что выходили за последние несколько лет. Абсурдный, но потрясающе смешной сюжет способен удержать у экрана практически любого любителя жанра, а удивительное внимание к деталям может заставить вас почувствовать, будто вы вновь окунулись в один из миров золотой эпохи Lucasarts, хотя на деле все обстоит немного иначе. 

Ретро-футуристический городок восточной Европы под названием Круш, переживший некую безымянную катастрофу (хотя, судя по его виду, может быть и не одну) и все его обитатели были созданы практически одним человеком - [i]Джейкобом Джанеркой[/i]. Этот независимый австралийский разработчик, успешно завершив свою кампанию на Кикстартере, бросил работу и полностью сфокусировался над разработкой игры. 

Через три года после окончания сбора средств - этот сюрреалистичный квест увидел свет, а я в то время уже успел было подумать, что в скором будущем все игры-адвенчуры будут выглядеть как линейные, красивые бродилки, где вы читаете записки и слушаете нарратив. Не поймите меня неправильно, в вышеупомянутом формате существует множество достойных представителей! Но после грандиозного провала Neverhood 2, я по-прежнему сидел на своем стуле с неутоленной жаждой классического тыканья во все объекты на экране, исключительно ради того, чтобы узнать, что они делают, а не для того, чтобы продвинуться по сюжету. 

Так вот [b]Paradigm[/b] (а также и несколько других отличных проектов в данном жанре, чей релиз состоялся в 2017-ом году) тогда пришелся как раз кстати. Все эти горы забавных взаимодействий с объектами, смешные диалоги и самоосознанное подражание классическим представителям жанра сплелись между собой в прекрасный проект, который способен порадовать как любителей point'n'click адвенчур, так и новых игроков. 

У [b]Paradigm[/b] в наличии также имеется отличный саундтрек и, не побоюсь сказать, уникальный визуальный стиль, а также дополнительный бонус в виде солидных в своем размере дневников разработки самого Джейкоба, вшитых прямо в игровой процесс. Для того, чтобы создать себе личную репродукцию головы независимого австралийского разработчика в любой момент геймплея, вам нужно лишь нажать на кнопку "J" и, если захочется, послушать истории о том, как создавалась игра. Здесь есть очень много любопытного материала, варьирующегося от зарождения идей до технической реализации некоторых аспектов игры. Но, если вам это все же абсолютно по боку, а головешку вы вызвали случайно, то не забывайте, что повторное нажатие кнопки позволит вам сжечь (!) голову Джейкоба и забыть всю эту нудятину как страшный сон.

В общем, если вы давно подумывали о том, чтобы поиграть в хороший, но при этом еще не выученный наизусть, point'n'click квест, а также если вы просто любите от души посмеяться, то искренне рекомендую провести здесь свою долю человеко-часов. Вы не пожалеете!

[b] P.S: А вообще я написал этот обзор, в связи с тем, что номинировал игру в категории [i]«Душа Витрувия»[/i] на Steam Awards 2017. Потому что, если Парадигм и его говорящие опухоли не выглядят как идеал телосложения, то тогда я даже не знаю... [/b]

36283312.review:
Although the game could have been a bit longer, I thoroughly enjoyed [i]every moment[/i] of it. The humour was extraordinary, the characters were endearing and the story kept me engaged throughout. (Not to mention the outstanding visuals and a beautiful soundtrack by Jonas Kjellberg!) Sometimes I found the puzzles to be a little too ridiculous, but to me, this only added an extra layer of nostalgia, thinking back to classic Sierra games of yesteryear.
Some might argue that the game is a tad too expensive considering its short length, but I think that that factor is greatly outweighed by the sheer flood of love and care that was put into this game. The quality of this point and click gaming experience is simply unmatched at this price point.

So glad this could be successfully funded on Kickstarter! If the game itself or its humour sparks your interest to [i]any degree[/i], this is an absolute must-buy!

36232568.review:
기존에 존재하는 패러다임을 완강히 거부한다!!

세기말스러운 병맛의 끝장을 선보이는 게임이다. 그 병맛이 어느정도인지 궁금하다면, 이목구비가 각기 다른 개성을 자랑하고 불량감자와도 같은 경악스러운 두상을 지닌 주인공 패러다임의 생김새만 봐도 어느 정도 짐작이 가능하리라. 그 밖에 주요 등장인물로는 비트박스가 주특기인 뒤틀린 가지처럼 보이는 말하는 식물, 말하다가 캔디 바를 토해내는 야심가 나무늘보, 머리와 사지가 해괴하게 결합이 된 과학자 등이 있다. 주인공을 비롯한 등장인물부터가 범상치 않은 병맛의 오라를 뿜는다.

세기말 동유럽 배경에 모든 장소는 황폐하고 영재 아이를 매매하는 심각하기 그지없어 보이는 배경이지만, 게임은 시종일관 그딴게 대수냐는 듯 유쾌하고 병맛스럽게 흘러간다. 대체로 고전 어드벤처 게임들의 흐름과도 비슷한 부분이긴 한데, 패러다임은 그런 고전 게임들보다도 훨씬 그 선을 넘어간 느낌이다. 아마 몬티 파이튼의 영화가 세기말을 다뤘다면 딱 이런 느낌이 되지 않을까 싶다.

뿐만 아니라 다양한 다른 게임들의 패러디가 가득하며 화면 전환도 상당히 빠르다. 게임의 줄거리가 상당히 빠른 템포로 전개된다. 덕분에 지루할 일은 없지만, 반대로 정신 사납게 느껴질 여지는 있다. 그것도 보통 정신 사나운 게 아니라 온갖 비정상과 병맛, 유머가 그야말로 쉴 새 없이 몰아치니... 그야말로 이 세상 것이 아닌 듯한 광경들이 끊임없이 쏟아져 나오는데, 병맛 코드를 좋아한다면 더 없이 만족스럽게 즐길 수 있을 게임일 것이다.

다만 게임플레이 자체는 고전 어드벤처 게임의 그것과 동일한 부분이 많다. 각 장소를 돌아다니며 힌트 파악하고 아이템 획득 대화를 통해 스토리를 진행해나가는 방식. 고전적인 방식이고, 그만큼 헤멜 여지가 많긴 하다. 그래도 난이도가 세 단계로 잘 갖춰져있어 가장 쉬운 난이도로 플레이하면 스토리 진행하는 데에 큰 지장은 없다. 물론 말은 이렇게 해도 오브젝트 보이는대로 클릭하면서 주인공 패러다임의 만담도 즐기고 도전과제도 조금씩 신경써주는 편이 더 재밌긴 하겠지만. 

어처구니 없어보일 높은 평점이 납득이 가는 상당한 완성도를 자랑하는 어드벤처 게임이다. 다만 게임 자체의 병맛이 워낙 진하다보니 일부 게이머들에게는 거부감이 살짝 있을지도. 그래도 한글화만 된다면 닥치고 추천하고 싶은 게임.

At first, it was difficult for me to understand why I found this game so depressing and obnoxious, but here’s a few thoughts.
I think the game is supposed to have this black humor. Indeed, it‘s pointing out stereotypical things that the author seems to consider ugly and inferior. It also mentions tumors, environmental crisis and other things that are considered taboo in the family friendly comedy, and one must be a true knight of black humor (south park grade) to dare fooling around them. But the thing is - just DARING to depict such things does NOT equal good jokes about them. And no, adding butts and balls to all this trivia does not help either. I need a joke in my fart joke, otherwise it’s just a fart.
Having one hour spent in the game and then returning it, I felt like it was a really shameful waste of time. It’s like reading a private diary of some very narcissistic and snobbish person, and having to pay real money to do so! Thanks but no thanks.

34917416.review:
With its attention to artistic detail and the kind of smart-stupid humor that sets lovable losers of my ilk tittering with childish glee, [i]Paradigm[/i] is a point-and-click adventure that more than lives up to its Kickstarter promise.  I can't say I expected much several years ago, when the original trailer showed off its gloriously greasy artwork, a style that mixes Salvador Dali with the too-close-for-comfort close-ups of [i]Spongebob[/i] or [i]Ren & Stimpy[/i]; some things are just too good to get in quantity.  The game, however, pulls it all off and more, lacing its ten hours of painstaking graphical work with awesome humor, clever (but never ball-breaking) puzzles, smooth electronica that would be right at home in a 1970's informational reel, and countless unique ideas.  [i]Saturated[/i] is almost what you'd call it -- there's something to look at, or laugh at, or play with tamped into every crevice.

Believe it or not, there's something more in [i]Paradigm[/i]:  a kind of wholesome affirmation about the value of life, even when that life is none too pleasing to the eye.  In this and many other ways, it was an adventure that kept me surprised and engaged through the very end.

This is a great game that taps into the nostalgic side of the brain of any of the classic point-and-click adventure gamers. The humor is obviously twisted (which I enjoyed, and found quite refreshing), but also finds its way into many tech-pop culture allusions. Paradigm finds a way to make clever social commentary about intelligence, status, and social value; however, it manages to do all this without taking itself seriously.

The puzzles are challenging enough, but not to the point where they get in the way of progress or enjoyment. There was one puzzle near the end of the game that I found quite awkward and difficult to solve; besides that one hitch, the consistency of the puzzle challenges was well thought out. The atmosphere was great, and was extremely effective at giving you an 80's synth/retro throwback ambience.

Overall, Paradigm is a game that stays faithful to the character of classic adventure games that people like me love, however it manages to bring something completely new to the table with its unique sense of twisted humor, graphics, and refreshing brand of story-telling.

I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who's looking to have some fun and laugh while they're at it (regardless of genre preference).

It took me a while to play through this because each time I entered a new screen it was such a sensory overload that I needed to take a break. It's bursting at the seams with weird art, bizarre conversations, cultural references, and digressions.

I think you need to be an adventure game fan to enjoy this. It can occasionally seem directionless with frustrating puzzle logic. But it definitely fits in the modern era of adventure games, making most stuff work on the first attempt and gently hinting in the right direction on failure.

Any problems are pretty easy to forgive because the game has such original character. The rapid fire jokes and voice acting are used perfectly throughout with each character having some lovable personality. There's also lots of surprises where the game breaks out of its low budget style and amps up the presentation for an expensive joke. It's really impressive the lengths it will go for a laugh.

33381705.review:
To me it feels like a damn shame Paradigm received so little media coverage and spotlight on release. Honestly, the humour is so good it could be considered a classic in the modern adventure game scene. I'm pretty sure it will get a cult following in time; perhaps a Church of the Later Day Paradigm.

You play as a mutated human with the self esteem of a jar in a post-nuclear, post-neo-comunist Eastern Europe who only wants to be left alone to do mad beatsies for the discotec. I don't want to spoil to much of the story, but have a look over the game's shared screenshots by the user and check the trailer (it's pretty damn funny). The settings makes for some beautiful sceneries and design, in that "weird as f*ck" kind of way.

Not too long (finished it in about 10 hours) the game is very well made, with most puzzles fairying on the easy side. For us adventure-impaired gamers (who love adventure games but suck at them) there's also an in-game hint system that's pretty good. I'm even thinking of doing another playthrough just to make sure i didn't miss any jokes.

There are also quite a few mini-games around, some to be discovered and some as part of the main storyline. Like everything else, they ooze with humor. Even the menu does. This is the kind of adventure game that rewards even the most mundane methods of exploration (like talking to every object or trying to pick it up, just to hear what Paradigm will say).

If I have to critique the game i'd have a hard time, but some of the repeating jokes do get a bit stale (like paradigm's lack of self-esteem) and the ending, while hilarious, raises a lot of unanswered questions.
I recommend getting this, even if it's full price. You will not be dissapointed.

Here's to hoping we will see a Paradigm 2: The Quest for Fat Beatsies.

33291115.review:
[H1]An impressive and funny indy point and click adventure game[/H1]
This game was created by Jacob Janerka with the help of a handful of people who provided the music and voice overs. The game is set in some unnamed Eastern European country in the near future after an unknown apocalypse has taken place. The main character is Paradigm. He is a shy, insecure, heavely disfigured mutant who stumbles upon a plot to overtake what is left of the world. The game doesn't take itself very seriously and it's main goal is to entertain. Most of the puzzles are easy while some are more challenging, but they never go overboard like in the Lucasarts adventure where the solution of some puzzles required up to a dozen steps that sometimes defied logic (but were so funny, we didn't care). The amount and general quality of the voice work is above average. Many characters are voiced by Jacob and all of the voice actors provided half a dozen voices, but this wasn't noticable or distracting (well done guys). Some are really good, some are mildly annoying, but overall they do a good job and bring the characters alive. One of the things that impressed and entertained me is that every interaction with every object in the game has unique spoken lines. Not only is there a seperate voice over for each description of an object. But the lines spoken when you talk to an object, try to use it or pick it up are unique for each object. 
One of the running gags in the game is that Paradigm is so incredibly lonely that when he can't physically pick an object up, he'll use his most sensual voice and drop a pick up line instead. After about a dozen of these pick-up lines you'd think that the developer wouldn't be able to think of any more. But you'd be wrong, there are dozens upon dozens of them in the game. The humour is never ROLF funny or even LOL funny, but the self referential and fourth wall breaking jokes had me smiling all throughout the game. The enormous amount of spoken lines do make it tiresome to play after a while, I recommend playing this games in small doses or just rush through the first time and listen to all descriptions a second time. 
The graphics are worth a mention as well. While somewhat disturbing at times (but never really gross), they are also sharp, crisp and well drawn. The game also features some mini games with more retro pixelated graphics which are also well done. The mini games are not very challenging and instead go for laughs, much like the rest of the game.
Paradigm is a lovable anti-hero despite his stocky body and large tumors on his head, I couldn't help but symphatise with the guy. Despite the constant sexual innuendo the game manages to never cross the boundaries. Don't go in expecting a game like leisure Suit Larry, it's not a dating simulator. Having said that, there is a mini game where you can actually date three mutant love interest and like the other mini games they are played for laughs. 
There are also numerous references to classic adventure games and pop culture. All in all a lot of love was put into this game. And there are a lot of funny details to be spotted.
The game isn't too long, it should take you about six to eight hours to finish and about double that if you listen to each and every description and play the game again so you can hear the creators comments in every screen. 
In conclusion this game is highly recommended to people who enjoy games like Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle and similar classics. I can only that this game is the first of many to come from Jacob Janerka, I really enjoyed the visuals, voicework, story and many jokes he put into this game.

Even if you aren't a fan of point and click adventures, I recommend that you play this game.

I backed this on Kickstarter, and I'm glad I did. 
Brilliant game made in the fashion of classic point-and-clicks like Sam and Max, Day of the Tentacle, or Space Quest. You take the role of Paradigm, a regular mutant in a regular faux-Eastern bloc country, Krusz, trying to finish his mixtape.

31828161.review:
(Note: Steam lies on the number of hours I spent in this - was closer to 8 hours, I believe)

Holy poops, folks. This was fantastic.

You definitely have to be tolerant of both absurdist and sometimes 'random' narratives in order for this to be your jam. So, if the trailer doesn't appeal to you this is probably not the droid you're looking for - but if the trailer had you hooked, like I was, then you're in for a great ride!

The story and visual style are amazingly consistent throughout the entirety of the game - something I was a bit concerned about jumping in ("They can't possibly keep this up!") The narrative has just the right amount of self-loathing and societal mockery to keep reminding the player that, while everything on the surface is goofy and delightfully ridiculous - there are darker realities on the peripheral.

The puzzles, I felt, were very well done - I never had a moment where I was confused to the point of being frustrated. Confrustrated. Frustfused. They were also just the right amount of challenging to make me feel like I had really solved something.

Also, the sound track. And the voice acting. And the cut scenes. And the detail work on every prop and character. Woooweee. It's impressive. A fist bump and high five to everyone involved in this wonderfully deranged  [strike] piece of art [/strike]  FISCALLY RESPONSIBLE TAX-DEDUCTION.

31725023.review:
Paradigm is a great journey for nostalgic fans of Lucas Art's Point and Click games. With multiple references to Day of the Tentacle, Monkey Island, and more, this game still deliver's its own bizare story that is worth the trip. The art is beautiful (and varied which is refreshingly unexpected) and plays on many pop culture references for added LoL's.

While it may seem odd at first, the story in all is quite solid. The puzzles complicated, but not to any unsolvable degree (I was able to complete it without needing to look up a walk through - just decent dedication to problem solving). The characters are fantasic (especially the mutated pharmasutical octopus Steph).

If there was one complaint I'd make, its that its in a 2 Act Structure opposed to a hopeful 3 Act story. This can leave the player a little disapointed when the ending suddenly appears, but not to any degree you feel cheated. Some people may be turned off by the inuendo and drug-use-based comedy, but past that hurdle is a great adventure that is worth taking.

All in all I do recomend the game. I even spoke to its creator and he's a great guy who loves feedback on his work. This is an indi designer who should be supported. So please do so if able and enjoy the good times :)

Do you like "Meanwhile in Soviet Russia" jokes? Do you like nipple references? Do you enjoy absurd stories? Do you like clicking things?
If you answered any of the above with yes, then this might be the right game for you!

It honestly isn't very long, but the actual playtime does differ considering your puzzle-solution skills (and your willingness to listen to some of the characters talk). Personally, I managed to get all the puzzles done without help and felt they were pretty "logical" (at least inside the game world).
The characters are completely over the top, ranging from weird, but cute to absolutely insane. They are also completely voice-acted, which is a big plus in my book. The voice acting is very well executed, as well.

The best thing about this, though, is its humor. Granted, everybody's take on humor might be a different one and you might find yourself unable to laugh at tumor jokes, but I got lucky and had a blast! I laughed so many times and so loud that I was afraid the neighbours would come over and ask if I was alright. The actual story can be rushed through if you like, but don't do that. You're gonna miss so many silly one-liners, dad jokes and in general just ridiculous writing, it'd be a shame.

My personal hint: Try to "Pick up" everything. I mean it.

31576151.review:
[i][h1]Paradigm(패러다임)은[/h1][/i] 보통 특정 논문의 글귀나 학문적 개념을 뒷받침하기 위한 뜻으로 쓰이나, 여기에서는 게임의 원제며 주인공의 이름이다.

심상치 않은 캐릭터의 외형과 스크린샷만 참조해도 본 작품은 타 포인트 앤 클릭 게임들과 차별성을 띠는 상당히 독특한 면을 지니고 있음을 알 수 있다. 

스토리 전개는 시작부터 괴이한 광고가 등장한다. 

DUPA(=폴란드어 뜻으로는 A$$)라는 유전공학 대기업이 부유한 상류층과 기득권층을 대상으로 특정한 '무언가'를 상품가치로서 시중에 판매한다. 이 '무언가'는 다름아닌 아이들이다.  자식이 부모를 선택할 수 없듯이, 부모 또한 자식을 선택할 수 없다. 거금의 양육비를 들여 키운 자식은 부모의 생각대로 자라주지 않는다. 그러나 DUPA사는 이를 가능하게끔 만들어준다.

우월한 유전인자만을 추출하여 오로지 천재적 특성만을 지닌 아이들을 인공배양함으로서, 후에 실험실에서 태어난 아이들은 결함도 없고 장애도 없는 '완벽한' 존재다. 부모는 저들의 입맛대로 커스터마이징한 아이를 '구입'하고 이들의 성장을 지켜보며 일종의 대리만족을 느끼는 것이다. 

광고가 끝나고 본격적으로 중심 인물이 등장한다. 그러나 그의 모습은 앞서 광고했던 완벽함과 우월함이라고는 찾아 볼 수 없으며, 외관 또한 눈살을 찌푸릴 만큼 경악스럽다.
게임은 '이것'을 컨트롤하도록 떠맡긴다. 호기심에 앞서 이곳저곳 클릭하여 나오는 대사와 배경을 접하다보면 슬슬 흥미가 돋아난다. 자국어 억양이 강한 주인공의 영어 음성부터 귀에 착착 달라붙고, 클로즈업 된 주인공의 얼굴을 물끄러미 들여다보면 저도 모르게 웃음을 머금게 된다.

초기 목적인 A를 위해 B를 찾아나서지만 B를 얻기위해서 C가 필요할 것이며, C의 부속 목적인 D가 필요한 상황에 놓이다가, 어느순간부터 원래 목표조차 잊어버리고 만다. [strike]병맛은 거기서 멈추지 않는다.[/strike]

게임 진행 도중 유일하게 인간 여성의 외형적 이미지를 지닌 NPC가 둘 등장하지만,  주인공은 이들과 썸을 타기는 커녕 말도 버벅거린다. 대신 주변사물에 인격체를 부여하여 대화를 나누고 은근슬쩍 작업을 건다. 자기비하에 블랙 코미디스러운 대사라 안쓰러울 지경임에도, 그만큼 재치있고 위트가 넘쳐서 보는 사물마다 상호작용을 유도한다. 또한 게임은 본의아니게 플레이어의 외국어능력을 테스트한다. 귀로는 폴란드어와 독일어를 듣고 눈으로는 영어 대사를 판별하며 머리는 이를 모국어로 통역하는 데 힘 써야 하는 구간이 나온다. (퍼즐이라기보단 언어적 유희가 돋보였다.) 
단순한 여정으로 시작한 전개는 더 나아가 위에서 언급한 DUPA사와 밀접한 연관성을 드러낸다. 

패러다임은 장면마다 개발진들이 심어놓은 상상력이 넘쳐흐른다. 게임 내에서 상식이란 쓸모없는 요소일 뿐이며, 그것을 대신할 엉뚱하면서도 적절한 요소가 다분하여 지루할 틈이 없다.
 
호주 아티스트 Jacob Janerka가 게임 원화 및 성우 역할 등 전반적인 게임 개발에 수고를 들였고, 스웨덴 아티스트 Jonas Kjellberg가 오디오 및 음악을 담당했다.

Cupcake/10

31390953.review:
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
Paradigm is a surreal futuristic point-and-click adventure game from indie developer, Jacob Janerka.

You play Paradigm, an unemployed mutant DJ and master of 'phat beatsies', leaving in a futuristic Eastern Europe where people can be genetically tailored. You live in a power station in Krusz, a town of five people situated on top of all of the world's radioactive waste. Nice hey?

The game starts with you wanting to finish your latest EP, but being unable to get your computer working. Consulting JOHN-3000, the ex-TV-dating-show AI that lives with you, you find out that a hacker has corrupted your system and you need to find a floppy disk in order to restore it, and also save the world from ultimate destruction!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics in Paradigm are mostly very good. While much of the game takes place with rendered / animated characters over still, drawn backgrounds, there are also a number of interludes and other sections with differing graphical styles, providing considerable contrast. But the quality is consistent throughout.

There are no graphics settings.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The background music, where present, went largely unnoticed, but isn't bad by any means. The game also includes some musical tracks to fit the story. Sound effects are appropriate and mostly well made.

The game is fully voiced, but the quality of voice actors and recordings varies quite a lot, with some sounding very professional, and others that sound like the developer putting on a bad accent and speaking into a microphone. Normalisation, again, is quite variable, though mostly good; there are still a few sections where volume trails off and it can be hard to make out what is being said by some characters.

Subtitles are included, though, so you won't miss anything.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Paradigm plays like a typical modern point-and-click adventure. Using the mouse to control Paradigm, you can interact with a vast array of useful and completely irrelevant or useless items, objects, and beings in Krusz and elsewhere. Left click moves Paradigm and right click opens up the interaction menu, which allows him to look at, talk to, use, or pick up the designated target. Moving the mouse pointer to the top of the screen opens the options menu, for saving and loading games or accessing the map, while moving the pointer to the bottom opens up Paradigm's typical adventure game inventory. It's a simple interface and brings nothing new to the genre, but it works well.

The largely nonsensical story wouldn't work that well as a short story or novella, but as a comedy adventure game it's great. Paradigm's world is a weird one, indeed. You'll encounter a cast of unique, but insane characters, and find yourself in very unusual situations. There's a constant barrage of puns, jokes, and innuendo, too, with almost every use of the 'pick up' action resulting in Paradigm eliciting some sort of groan-worthy pick-up line. The game breaks the fourth wall on a few occasions, and includes countless references to pop-culture and memes; I'm sure I didn't pick up on all of them, but those I saw gave me a smile or chuckle. The humour probably won't be for everyone, but within a few minutes of play you should be able to work out whether you'll enjoy it or not.

There are some rather silly mini-game sections, which provide some fun distractions, as well as some short FMV sections, which were well made.

Given the amount of writing in the game, I wasn't surprised to see a few typos and grammatical errors, but the quality of the text is generally very good.

Despite the general silliness inherent in the game, the puzzles make sense and most savvy adventure game players shouldn't require continual access to a walkthrough. The developer has provided one on the game's website, though, so it's there if you need it.

The game is relatively short -- I'd estimate it would take most people somewhere between four and six hours depending on their play style. It took me a little longer as I alt-tabbed to make comments for my review. It includes Steam Achievements that are missable; I'm not really fond of these in point-and-click adventures, which inherently have very little replayability. I don't think I'll bother going back and replaying the game just to pick up the achievements I missed.

[h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1]
Pros:
+ A crazy sense of humour
+ A generally likeable protagonist
+ Puzzles make sense
+ Fully voiced
+ Good graphics
+ Achievements and Trading Cards

Cons:
- Some voices aren't the best
- Relatively short

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
Paradigm is a well-made and enjoyable comedy point-and-click adventure game. Fans of the genre who also appreciate puns, bad jokes, and pop-culture references should definitely pick it up.

31182755.review:
As a kickstarter backer I had pretty high expectations for Paradigm, especially considering how long this has taken to come out. I'm an avid point and click adventure fan and the dark humour here is exactly my kind so it seemed like it would be a great game to fund.  
 
Boy I wasn't wrong. 
 
Those looking for really challenging puzzles will be slightly disappointed as there aren't many in sight. The puzzles are for the most point fairly straight forward, but the story telling, world setting and humour throughout is great. 

Not trying to "spoil" anything here, but from a conversation standpoint in the game, it's generally the last dialogue choice that would be the one that would progress the game. Decent decision here from the developer as I'm sure many point and click fans love hearing all dialogue trees when meeting or talking to characters. So naturally working your way down a dialogue list from top to bottom means you won't skip any interesting backstory.

Took me roughly 8 hours to complete and I picked up most of the achievements along the way.

If you're an old school point and click fan, it's perhaps not up to standards of recent games like the Deponia series but still a great one to have in your collection.

Hopefully this isn't the last game Jacob makes because the guy clearly has a talent here.

If there is a game you are going to get this year it should most definately be Paradigm. This charming little game succedes in both being a weird comedic look at the hyperbole of a dystopian future where genetic engineering begins to replace natural means of reproduction and also the adverse affects it has on those genetically engineered people. 

It is able to make meta jokes in the most charming and dynamic of ways, never breaking the mood of the game and contributing to the consistent pacing and flow.

31095571.review:
Damn, I love this game, certainly the most enjoyable point and click adventure in years. This isn't because it involves some grand journey involving dozens of playable characters, and it's not because it tells an epic story that will be passed down through generations. No, it's because it's completely silly and - more importantly - extremely funny. Most of the comedy adventures that I've played, no matter how good they are, barely raise a smile, but Paradigm had me laughing on a regular basis. Of course, this all depends on your sense of humor, but I'd say if you like your humor less anodyne you'll probably enjoy it.

You play as Paradigm, a guy with no nose, bulging eyes, and large tumors on his head. But you'll quickly learn that he has a heart of gold, and more importantly a dry and witty view of the world. This isn't particularly a puzzle-heavy game, it's more a case of exploring the bizarre town of Krusz and interacting with its insane inhabitants. Don't get me wrong, there certainly are puzzles, and you'll be combining things from your inventory and interacting with the world plenty of times, but the learning curve is quite gentle, and the developer never lets a puzzle get in the way of a good joke. Literally everything that you can interact with (and there are plenty of interactables on each screen) can be examined, spoken to, used or picked up, usually with comic effect. There aren't any cat moustach puzzles here, it's all pretty logical, but does require some thought towards the end.

The artwork is excellent, a detailed, hand-painted style that's often intentionally grotesque, and often quite funny with visual jokes scattered around. There's also great attention to detail everywhere, lots of little cool and unexpected things that happen as a result of interactions that show just how much work and passion has gone into this thing. The music is excellent, often sounding like something from Boards of Canada's back catalogue. That's when you're not listening to phat beatsies (and you will). The voice work is also impressive, not a dud performance anywhere. Released in the same week as Thimbleweed Park, you might think Paradigm could get overlooked, but it shouldn't. Frankly, I think I enjoyed this more. I'm reassured that there's still plenty of imagination and fun to be had in point and click adventure games.

The art style was unique and I very much appreciated the references to old point and clicks in a subtle 'nod' kind of way. It was clear that the creators respected its influences without piggybacking.

The story was an oddball one, yet didn't go off the rails too much. It was linear enough to remember what you were doing, and there was plenty of available prompts in case you forget/ have to come back at a later date.

The humour was constant, and sometimes cliched/ forced. A lot of the time it was internet culture-based. I get the feeling that much of the humour will be dated in no time at all. The difficulty could have been notched up a bit.

Overall though, the game was great fun, I found myself itching to come back to it a few hours after I stopped. Good work! I'd love to see more games from these guys.

31032263.review:
If you enjoy adventure games from the past like those from Sierra or Lucas Arts, then you really owe it to yourself to play Paradigm.

It's a refreshing and well-made adventure game that stays true to old-skool point & click games control scheme all while bursting at the seams with a bizarre humor, witty dialog (all voiced), interesting puzzles, phat beatsies, and its all crammed into a beautifully detailed, hand crafted world. 

The only 2 weaknesses I could possibley levy against the game is that 1, the puzzles are slightly easier than past classics, but mostly because Paradigm doesn't rely on unintuitive "use out of place objects on each other until something works" puzzle design. The second being the length of the game. I took my time and still beat Paradigm in only 6 hours. While that 6 hours were great fun and totally worth the price of admission, I really wanted to continue the story and play more in the world the creator had made.

Its surprising Paradigm isn't being talked about more on the internet.
If you're a fan of adventure games, you won't be disappointed with Paradigm.

31013729.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
A surreal and extremely funny point and click adventure game that includes ample references to the 1970s and 1980s, with a look and feel that is both nostalgic but original, and certainly captures the imagination. 

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
Although some point and click adventure games can be frustratingly obscure, or mechanically obtuse, that is not the case here. An intuitive investigation and inventory system assists, rather than hinders, your exploration of the game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The art style of this game is incredible. Every little detail simultaneously marries together the consistent theme, while also being memorable and unique at the same time. Players who spend time looking at all areas of the world are rewarded by the attention to detail with funny, entertaining, and bizarre hints at the history of the world.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Consistently funny dialogue, the writing of this game is perhaps it's second most adeptly executed feature, after the art style. Some memorable and highly quotable lines. The music is also well done, and captures the nostalgia of the intended era well.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
An unforgettable experience, if you're a fan of well written games or point and click games in general, then I highly recommend this game.

31007975.review:
Paradigm might just be one of the funnier and more ludicrous games I've played in some time. Be warned, I did back this game on Kickstarter and my visage can be found hanging out with some real cool backers. If you feel that this review is thus hopelessly skewed beyond credibility, feel free to rage quit this review, uninstall Steam and delete your Facebook account to emphasize the point. I promise to feel the full wrath of your anger and then remind you I'm a tenured professor so I truly don't care. Oh, and you still owe me that homework assignment. Oh, I also played the game in beta so this review is out so quick based on that beta playthrough.

Back to Paradigm. Paradigm is the least likely hero you are likely to encounter unless you hang with genetically mutated guys with low self esteem issues living in a deteriorating nuclear power plant. Can you keep the plant intact? Can you help Paradigm with a sentient eggplant that owes him rent? Will Paradigm survive his encounter with a guy who clearly is not  a drug dealer? These and other quests await you as you just try to get some sweet mix tapes made. 

Paradigm is one of the most original adventure games I have ever played. The puzzles range from easy to hard but there is a hint system (that literally is a little voice in your head) and there is always the helpful dog tutorial. Whoever thought up the word "quirky" might have had some idea that Paradigm would one day come along. This game is good fun, more than a little crazy and well worth the effort. There are the ever present inside jokes that seem to be so in vogue with modern games but they generally work and if you don't get them, no real harm done. The game does have some themes that are best not viewed by the very young so keep that in mind that this game is PG-13. If you don't like games that take themselves too seriously, you'll love Paradigm. I know I do.

Having played and replayed the demo for this game multiple times, I can say that this is exactly what I was hoping for. A point and click game with mountains of meta-humour and amazing art, some of which the creator made in live streams which bring me a great deal excitement when I see one of those objects in the game. It's like seeing your friend's new born baby 9 months after watching them have sex, truly emotional stuff. The gameplay is nothing particularly special. You have 4 ways of interacting with nearly every object in a scene, and half the fun in this game comes from using every one of those interactions on the individual objects and characters just to hear Paradigm say something funny. The jokes don't always hit, but when they don't I can quickly click on the object again and hear Paradigm use a pick-up line on a literal crack in a giant metal butt. As you can see I don't have too much time in this game yet, that is mostly because I played the demo so much, which lets you fully explore the first 2 areas of the game; the inside and outside of Paradigm's room, that I went as fast as possible to the new areas. Most of my play time after that has been devoted to interacting with every tiny, unimportant object because I cannot get enough of Paradigm's sexy pickup lines.

After two years of waiting for this game to be released, I can safely say this is everything promised to me and I love it. Here's hoping that the next game explores the tragic backstory of The Cone in much greater detail.

30964332.review:
Paradigm is an indie point-and-click adventure game that stems from the mind of Jacob Janerka, and it punches well above its weight in every category imaginable.

Paradigm does what all great point-and-click games do - provide a simple interface, then allow for every possible combination of command and item. It does this by subverting your gaming experience at every turn, most notably with the last of your four actions: the'pick up' command. Ordinarily, clicking on an unretreivable object would give you something like "I can't pick that up" as a catch-all response; in Paradigm, your character will unabashedly attempt to hit on said object, with a personalised pun, every, single, time. This meticulousness and attention to detail encourages the gamer into exploring every corner of the world, and rewards them with some truly cringeworthy pick-up lines.

The post-apocalyptic setting, in the ficitious Eastern Europe country 'Krusz', results in an absorbing mash-up of contemporary meme culture with a cold-war-era twist, replete with Python-esque accents and a dollop of fair dinkum aussie humour too. The characters break the 4th wall constantly, often to great effect, and whilst the game doesn't take itself too seriously, the story is compelling and deals with some proper sci-fi in a manner akin to Futurama - poking fun at interesting ideas and then pushing them to strange, hilarious places.

Paradigm is genuinely laugh-out-loud funny in places, with absurdist, tongue-in-cheek humour and a large dollop of madness. It's impossible for every single line of dialogue in an adventure game to hit the mark, and some of the more self-effacing humour belies a little insecurity about how the game would be received, but the designer needn't have worried as practically every interaction is rewarding, amusing and inventive. The artwork is truly excellent; a really surreal juxtaposition of colourful and macabre which takes inspiration from vintage tech, 80s pop-culture, and retro point-and-click gaming as well as a variety of other unexpected sources. The voice-acting, sound effects and music are absolutely on-point too, providing the game with a well-rounded and immersive feel. Some aspects of Paradigm's gaming experience are so well-crafted that they're like whole games within the game itself - in truth, I'd rather not reveal what they are, because part of the beauty of them is how they unexpectedly appear within the context of the story. The creativity and know-how required, not only think to envisage, but execute these ideas to such a high standard, is hugely impressive.

When you consider that this game was put together by a very small team with little prior experience, the quality of the final result is even more astounding. Aside from a few proof-reading niggles, and the puzzles perhaps proving too easy to solve (which connoisseurs of the genre may turn their nose up at), this is a stellar acheivement, and one which surely establishes Jacob and Jonas as shoe-ins for bigger things within the gaming industry in the future.

*4-HR REVIEW* :

I've now played around 4 hours of Paradigm clicking practically everything I can. A lewd, rude, unhinged and very funny homage to classic LucasArts SCUMM point-and-click games - a tremendous achievement thus far with a frankly brilliant level of detail for an independently-produced game.
